EXPERIMENT.TITLE: Gene expression profiling of diapause termination in E and Z strains of the European corn borer moth, Ostrinia nubilalis

DESIGN.DESIGN_DESCRIPTION: In order to understand evolved differences in the length of larval diapause termination for Z and E-strain European corn borers (Ostrinia nubilalis), we sampled three time points along the photoperiodically-initiated and terminated diapause developmental pathway. The first sampled time point occurred when both strains were in the diapause maintenance phase under short-day diapause inducing conditions (12:12 L/D). The second sampled time point occurred on day 1 after long-day exposure (16:8 L/D), but before a physiological change in respiratory metabolism in either strain ("day 1"). The final time point was sampled on day 7 after long-day exposure and after physiological divergence between strains ("day 7"). Head tissues were sampled to capture changes in major neuroendocrine glands and the primary endogenous clock. Five individuals were pooled for each of 5 replicates per strain per time point. Total RNA was extracted with the Qiagen RNeasy kit and prepared for next-generation sequencing using the TruSeq RNA Prep kit. Six libraries were multiplexed per lane and subjected to single-end 50 bp sequencing on an Illumina HiSeq 2000.

DESCRIPTOR.STUDY_TITLE: Gene expression profiling of diapause termination in E and Z strains of the European corn borer moth, Ostrinia nubilalis
DESCRIPTOR.STUDY_ABSTRACT: Evolutionary change in diapause timing will be key for insects to adapt to a globally warming climate. However, the molecular mechanisms behind shifts in diapause timing are still unclear. The European corn borer moth (Ostrinia nubilalis) shows evolved differences in the length of larval diapause termination, where Z-strain individuals have a long termination time and E-strain individuals have a short termination time. Here, we use whole transcriptome profiling of larval head tissues through a developmental time-course of diapause termination to, i) identify putative loci responsible for initiating divergence in diapause timing, and ii) identify downstream molecular pathways that may direct moths to an earlier or later end of diapause. As diapause is induced under short-day conditions (12:12 light:dark) and broken under long-day conditions (16:8 light:dark), we sample both strains under short-day conditions during diapause maintenance, and on days 1 and 7 after exposure to long-day conditions during diapause termination, to illuminate the critical mechanisms for observed shifts to seasonal timing.
DESCRIPTOR.CENTER_PROJECT_NAME: Ostrinia nubilalis strain:E and Z phermone strains

EXPERIMENT.TITLE: Gene expression profiling of diapause termination in E and Z strains of the European corn borer moth, Ostrinia nubilalis

DESIGN.DESIGN_DESCRIPTION: In order to understand evolved differences in the length of larval diapause termination for Z and E-strain European corn borers (Ostrinia nubilalis), we sampled three time points along the photoperiodically-initiated and terminated diapause developmental pathway. The first sampled time point occurred when both strains were in the diapause maintenance phase under short-day diapause inducing conditions (12:12 L/D). The second sampled time point occurred on day 1 after long-day exposure (16:8 L/D), but before a physiological change in respiratory metabolism in either strain ("day 1"). The final time point was sampled on day 7 after long-day exposure and after physiological divergence between strains ("day 7"). Head tissues were sampled to capture changes in major neuroendocrine glands and the primary endogenous clock. Five individuals were pooled for each of 5 replicates per strain per time point. Total RNA was extracted with the Qiagen RNeasy kit and prepared for next-generation sequencing using the TruSeq RNA Prep kit. Six libraries were multiplexed per lane and subjected to single-end 50 bp sequencing on an Illumina HiSeq 2000.
